name: Help requested -> the most powerful ECB Level 40 builds you would NOT want to face...?
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi everyone,

I've been less active in the ECB lately, been working on a large number of other projects.

One of the things I've been doing is helping out the WoG PW with a certain 'new epic adventure' designed for parties of characters level 36-40.

DM Wise has asked if the ECB would be willing to help with suggesting some of the most  powerful level 40 ECB builds a party wouldn't want to face. 

Mixture of warrior, rogue/sneakers, archers and divine and arcane casters would be great, even a spellsword or two perhaps.

These are some of his words

But something that might be representative of each type of character or character combo.  I can even give credit to the Character builder in the NPC description.  This might be a cool ECB/WoG crossover that player/builders get to see (and face) their creations from the other side of the table.

avoid spoilers and context, just that this is part of a project for the last and most epic adventure WoG has to offer, a destination for 40th level characters.  "40th level characters shouldn't retire -- this is just when it gets interesting
Anyway if you can help out with your top 5 suggestions that would be greatly appreciated. I'm happy to hear from anyone, new or experienced!

Environment specifics for those interested:
Spoiler -> harm/heal is limited to 250hp, True Seeing nerfed to providing Ultravision/See Invisibility and +20 spot, HiPS on a 6 second timer, E/IE disabled when casting spells, PnP TT (I think its +1 BAB every 2 caster levels)
If you need help finding builds:
SpoilerThe Epic Character Builder Forum Archives (2004-2010)
https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... archive-v2 https://www.tapatalk.com/groups/nwnecbguild/http://www.google.com
Hope you are all doing well, and staying safe. Thanks again for your help.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I would think that the AI is important here. Strong builds are at their best when played properly, using their strengths and covering their weaknesses.
An example is when a caster type spends time buffing when spawned in, he is dead meat before he can do any harm, or a fighter type with low will save without mind/fear protection that never will be able to attack.

I *think* WoG's custom AI can handle most things, Mick.

Those Casters on WoG either use Time Stop and buff (in an annoying TS spammed orgy), or are spawned in with some buffs (or more) active iirc.

Below is a list of class spreads for PvP builds, split into 5 categories. All of the builds are currently just theory builds, but I (or anyone else) can create a build guide in CBC if needed. None of the builds will be able to deal with Time Stop spam or epic trap stacking, but that would apply even if they were played by a skilled player.

I'm assuming that the builds can't use items, can't set traps, and don't need UMD. Every build with PM15+, Sorc21+, or Wiz21+ has Epic Warding. Some of the builds are hard to kill but lack any real offense, they might not be appropriate for this request. Some of the builds (especially HiPSers) require certain playstyles or tactics that the AI will struggle to use properly.

[DC] indicates Devastating Critical, [ED] indicates Epic Dodge, [ASS3] indicates Automatic Silent Spell 3.
Anything marked with * probably won't work for this request, either due to alignment restrictions or because the AI will struggle to play it properly.
AB/AC values are all rough estimates, effective AB/AC has been excluded. They assume a balanced (not minmaxed) build, +5 AB/EB weapons, +5 AC items, Haste, and +12 to all relevant abilities. Ranged AB for all DEX Melee builds is roughly the same as the listed melee AB.

I don't know what sort of gear is available on WoG, but every build should aim to have 29 Fortitude, 27 Reflex, 27 Will, and 50 Discipline after ability bonuses. Most of the builds can fit in Listen/Spot if vanilla True Seeing is unavailable, although effective detect requires Keen Sense which limits race choice to elf. 5/- or 10/- Magic DRes gear is needed against IGMS spam. Some of the builds can fit in EER: Cold 3+ for Ice Storm spam but Cold DRes gear will be useful too. Most of the melee builds will need Acid and Fire DRes gear to deal with damage shields unless paired with a build that can breach.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
The builds that we make here are based on what is accessible for players to build and play, be it for PvM or PvP.
They work best when played the way they are intended to. There are a lot of tactics. Some are good for some builds other tactics are good for other builds. Player skill (from a skilled player so to speak) is far better than any AI I have seen so far. Unless the AI is very good, going up against player builds will be like PvP against a weak or moderatly skilled player.
When you make creatures in the toolset, you are not limited to the player rules. You are free to create "monsters". They can be far more challenging than any creature limited by the player rules.
The most challenging encounters can often be when there spawn in groups of different creatures that supplemented each other, comparable to a traditional adventuring party and if archers and mages are difficult to reach for melee characters.

So when we propose builds, it is of importance how they are implemented in the PW and what tactics the AI can handle properly. Experienced WoG players can probably say more about the strengths and limitations of the AI.
I would also suggest that we think of groups/parties of characters that can work well together to increase the challenge.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I think the concept has merit and is interesting (as well as appealing to our egos as motivators, of course !). However, it kind of walks the same path as our Hall of Fame thread, with the same inherent problems - including not even fully agreeing parameters, let alone finalizing which builds to include! Thus, it died on the vine, never reaching conclusive results, despite best intentions from all parties.

I don't mean for this to sound negative - as I said, I like the concept. I think Mick has presented the other potential problems - and at least when playing our builds we get to improve our playstyles and skills, but when handing them over to AI to implement it could get tricky if it doesn't do what the creator knows it should/could do.

I do hope something concrete can be made here, I'm just not quite sure what atm (though I do rather like Mick's idea for "tag teams" or small parties, I confess).

Cheers

I'd even go further than you and say that not only do our tactics make the builds better, but also MANY of our tactics are pretty much designed to exploit faulty AI. How else do you explain monsters literally suiciding on a Damage-shielded, Epic-Warded Wizard / PM? Pulling an enemy into a green carpet of traps, as it blindly runs to its death with no "second thoughts". No matter what we say about this game and how improved WoG AI truly is, the AI in this game, complex as it is, couldn't feasibly be programmed to mimic a PvP build. 

That's also why PvP is a completely different monster and builds that excel at it wouldn't necessarily excel at PvM. I honestly don't know how good my Magical Master would be at PvP. Possibly good, but I can't say for sure. What would he be facing? What tactics would work? How many immunities would be present? He is the most amazing PvM build I've EVER played. Not a single build I've made comes even close to what this guy can do. This is coming from the guy who made Champion of the Wilderness, The Shadow Priest and Demolition Man, 3 of the most played and powerful builds in the guild. Having played all of them to 40, the discrepancy in power is BRUTAL. I can't stress that enough. Where the Shadow Priest would break a sweat to solo an encounter, the Magical Master just cruises through, sometimes killing the enemy without even getting hit once. But I doubt the AI would be able to do what I do when I play him. 

For a Wizard / Cleric, when you memorize spells, you memorize multiple copies of them because you have to last through the day, and you conserve your spells for tougher battles, even if it takes longer to kill some wasy mobs. Sometimes I don't even buff with my long-term buffs, except EMA until the final battle or an underboss or something. You normally prepare spells that would work against the enemy you're planning to face, not "a spell for each possible enemy type", etc... As an example, when I face Drow, who are Spell Resistant, ALL my level 3 spells are Extended Death Armor, ALL my level 4 spells are Extended Haste, ALL my level 5 spells are Extended Elemental Shield, ALL my level 6 spells are Extended Mestil's Acid Sheath, All my level 7 spells are Extended Greater Stoneskin (and level 7 Cleric are Word of Faith cuz it penetrates SR), and ALL my level 8 slots are Premonitions. Alternatively, if I'm facing non-SR enemies, I'll take 3 of each of the shields or none, depending on how often I expect or even want to get hit, and memorize ALL IGMSs at 6, Bigby 7 / Extended Bigby 6 at 7 / Empowered IGMSs at 8, etc.. I normally cast from self-crafted scrolls A LOT, so I never memorize Bigby 9, but I have 50 stacks of Bigby 9 scrolls that I can use if need be. I also ALWAYS use Summon Creature 9 / Stoneskin to bait breaches from scrolls, and then I have 50 scrolls of Bigby 5 to lower enemy AB by 10, and 50 scrolls of Greater Sanctuary to escape, etc.... I don't think that kind of versatility can be replicated by the AI. Imagine an NPC casting Greater Sanctuary and just running away cuz the odds aren't in his favor that day? LOL.

Finally, there is a FUNDAMENTAL difference, an AI-controlled NPC needs to just survive this ONE battle, and be effective in it. I don't know how that would change memorized spells for the Magical Master. Perhaps I could think about a specific spell configuration for that build to fight a party of NPCs, but I don't even know in what order he'd cast them. It's too many options and too many variables, and one can't be prepared for "everything".

posts.author: Old Gith
posts.content:
Warm winds and hello!  DM Wise here.  Not much of a builder, but I created an account because Orion said a few of the folks had some more questions.  During the creation of my last project, I thought it might be an interesting to have a Guild Crossover between this Guild and WoG.  The shape this would take would be in the form of gladitorial-style arena combat.  While this in itself is easy enough to create and script, I thought it might even be more interesting to "bring to life", so to speak, some of the great character builds over the last few generations.  These would be enemy combatants, of course, and my end goal is to create multiple batches of such combatants that are randomized (to mitigate meta-gaming) over the course of three rounds, or arena events.

The AI is the AI and there's not much we can do about that at the moment, so waste no time on lamenting on this issue.

Most people know it's a mid-magic environment.  These contests will be 1 v 1, but I'm expanding it to 2 v 2 for a party, or a 2 v party.  I would prefer to keep the original name of the build provided it is generic enough to stay thematic without breaking immersion (for instance, "Panthro" would not be suited since now we're talking Thundercats).  I would also like a good little snippet to put in the description, as well as the author's name in the credits/description for the NPC.

I have plans to make it more robust as time moves on, but right now I'm in the infancy stage still.  It is up and running, and there currently are 3 combatants, but I would like to increase that to 12.  I would create these combatants using the toolset.  There is a way to create them that preserves their BAB, saves, etc.  I would outfit them with gear that would be appropriate for a 40th level character, but not get too carried away.  

I'll check in from time to time to see how the list is coming along.  Cheers!

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
For a proper challenge I would recommend a base of 2/3 mobs for 1 player and adding 1/2 more mobs for every additional player in the party. I'm also not sure how you will spawn the mobs but I recommend splitting them into categories and then spawning based on those categories. For example, if you spawn two mobs then one would be a melee build and one would be a caster, with more mobs changing the overall party composition. The spawned mobs could also be based on the player's builds, but that might require more effort than it's worth.

I recommend nerfing Time Stop (add a timer, only affect creatures within a radius instead of within an area, change the actual effect, disable completely, etc) and trap stacking in the area that these fights will take place in. Damage shields, Harm, Ice Storm, and IGMS are also problem spells that will need to be accounted for, either with DI/DR or spell changes. Relying on the AI to breach/dispel damage shields won't work for the simple reason that players are smarter than AI, consider adding a random chance to remove damage shields with OnHit weapons or every x seconds in the area. Limiting magic item use would also make for a better challenge, either by preventing it completely or by adding a limit of x uses per day once in the area.

I'm not sure what gear/effects the builds will have but at a minimum I'd recommend +12 to the relevant abilities (possibly +12 to all abilities), permahaste, +10ish universal saves, +25ish to all relevant skills (excluding Spellcraft), and 32 spell resistance. Consider adding basic spells (or spell-like abilities) such as Darkness, Improved Invisibility, Lesser Restoration, Negative Energy Protection, Silence, True Seeing, breaches, dispels, heals, and mantles to all of the builds. For DI/DR I'd recommend a minimum of 50% Negative DI and 5/- Magic DRes for all builds. Consider adding Divine DI/DR for certain spells and 50% Acid/Cold/Fire DI for Ice Storm and damage shields. Weapon damage and physical DI/DR are also important but they would need to be adjusted based on available player gear.

What sort of immunity gear will the mobs have access to?
For example if they all have access to mind spell immunity then the value of Monk20 and high will saves decreases.

What sort of immunity gear will the players have access to?
I'm aware that knockdown immunity is available on WoG, so the only real use for knockdown effects like KD/IKD, Bigby6, and Grease is to force players to equip knockdown immunity gear. If freedom gear is easily available then any Assassin build is useless (even more so than usual), immunities limit the useful spells that DC casters can use, etc.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
After thinking about this request a bit more, I don't think it's possible to provide any proper PvP builds for WoG without either editing the builds in the toolset or editing the environment they will be used in. The AB/AC values in my second post can be used as a guide for what a balanced level 40 build can achieve in a +5 environment, and also as a guide for potential builds that your mobs could face.

Most ECB builds are designed for PvM, and even the best PvM builds usually require some editing to become decent PvP builds. Fresh PvP builds could be designed with this specific environment in mind (which would require more information about what buffs/gear is available), but they would still not be good enough because WoG is not designed with PvP balance in mind.
So if you do choose to use ECB builds directly instead of as inspiration for toolset mobs you will need to change the environment to make the builds more threatening.

Some problem spells have been nerfed on WoG but they haven't been nerfed enough for a balanced PvP environment.
Harm being limited to 250 Negative damage and IGMS being limited to 15 missiles per target doesn't really matter when Time Stop > True Strike > Harm > Harm > Repeat or Time Stop > IGMS > IGMS > Repeat are still viable tactics. Even 50% Negative DI and 5/- Magic DRes would only change those damage cycles from 500 -> 250 damage and 360 -> 210 damage respectively, it wouldn't prevent the tactics from working. WoG's rest-limiting might prevent these tactics when facing multiple 2000+ HP mobs at once, but in a 1v1 fight (even three back-to-back) against an opponent with 700ish HP that won't be enough.
Damage shield stacking will be a big problem for almost every melee build, even with 50% Acid/Fire DI that's still 50ish damage per hit against high level mages.
Other spells such as Black Blade Of Disaster, Greater Sanctuary, Word Of Faith, healing (both items and spells), and speed increasing spells will also need to either be changed or balanced around in the arena.

Items also play a big part in PvP balance, such as available immunity gear and traps (particularly epic trap stacking).
However even things like unlimited Clarity potions, Lesser Spell Breach wands, and Mordenkainen's Disjunction scrolls have a large effect on what builds and tactics are viable. Any build that relies on buffs with less than 27 caster levels effectively doesn't have any buffs. Damage shields and mantles are borderline useless against prepared players. Casters are limited to a very small selection of spells (Flesh To Stone, Harm, Ice Storm, IGMS, Implosion, Undeath To Death (undead shifters only), Word Of Faith, etc) and even they can be effectively ignored if the player has enough mantle scrolls.
I'm not as concerned about melee/ranged damage since weapons can easily be created to deal with the 20/- DRes items that players have access to, but that's also something to bear in mind.

Devastating Critical is worth it's own thread, but I'll just say that there's a reason for most PvP servers either removing or editing Dev Crit.
Any mob that isn't critical immune and doesn't have absurd (85+) AC will die eventually regardless of how high it's Fort is. I suggest using a balanced Cler28/Bard2/RDD10 with +65 AB and full cleric casting as a benchmark PvP build for how powerful Dev Crit can be. It can force most opponents into becoming flatfooted and then use Dev Crit to finish off anything that Harm spam can't.
